channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans in Amsterdam Unfolded
item.description: Antisemitic assaults on visiting Israeli soccer fans, and incendiary chants and attacks by some Israelis: Here’s what we know so far about the violence in Amsterdam last week.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Extra security measures were put in place in Amsterdam after clashes involving supporters of the soccer club Maccabi Tel Aviv.

item.title: Taiwan Sees a Higher Price for U.S. Support as Trump Returns to Power
item.description: The president-elect’s call for Taiwan to spend more on its own defense and his complaints about its semiconductor dominance may herald a tenser relationship.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers during military exercises last year. Donald J. Trump has complained about Taiwan, saying: “They don’t pay us money for the protection, you know?”

item.title: Saudi Arabia Hosts a Tennis Final Won by Coco Gauff
item.description: The kingdom, which has been accused of trying to “sportswash” its human rights record, hosted the WTA Finals, part of its unstoppable advance into the world of sports.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Coco Gauff of the United States serving to Qinwen Zheng of China during the WTA singles final in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Saturday.

item.title: Trump’s Presidency Could Spell a Lonely and Dangerous Stretch for Europe
item.description: Internal political squabbles — and the fallout from a global backlash to inflation, immigration and ruling elites — are hobbling Germany and France.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, left, and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany in May in Meseberg, near Berlin.

item.title: Israeli Strike in Gaza Kills Over 30 Palestinians, Emergency Services Say
item.description: The strike hit a house in the city of Jabaliya, which has repeatedly come under attack as the Israeli military has pressed an offensive in northern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinians surveyed the destruction in Jabaliya, in northern Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: Palestinians Try to Sway Trump, Reaching Out to Tiffany Trump’s Relative
item.description: The Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas has met with Tiffany Trump’s father-in-law and written conciliatory letters to the president-elect, a strong supporter of Israel.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Charles Homans
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, and then-President Donald J. Trump in the West Bank city of Bethlehem in 2017.

item.title: Israeli Strike Kills 23 People North of Beirut, Lebanon Says
item.description: The strike in the Jbeil district of Lebanon came amid an apparent diplomatic push for a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Rescuers searching for survivors after an airstrike in the Lebanese village of Almat on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Says It Shot Down Waves of Ukrainian Drones Above Moscow
item.description: Officials said more than 30 drones had been intercepted over suburban areas of the Russian capital in what was the biggest such attack since the invasion of Ukraine in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Emergency responders at a damaged building after a drone attack in the village of Stanovoye in the Moscow region on Sunday.

item.title: Han Dongfang, Once China’s ‘Worst Nightmare,’ Refuses to Back Down
item.description: Neither jail nor exile to Hong Kong has stopped Han Dongfang, a former Tiananmen Square protest leader, from championing workers’ rights. “If you’re born stubborn, you go everywhere stubborn.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Han Dongfang is one of China’s last remaining labor rights activists not in hiding.

item.title: 50,000 Russian and North Korean Troops Mass Ahead of Attack, U.S. Says
item.description: Ukrainian officials expect a counteroffensive in western Russia to begin in the coming days as North Korea’s troops train with Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army vehicle passing through the destroyed Russian border post at the Sudzha crossing and entering Russia in August.

item.title: How World Leaders Are Prepping for a Second Trump Presidency
item.description: Foreign leaders have rushed to ingratiate themselves with Donald J. Trump in recent days, nervously recalling the clashes, insults and feuds of his first presidency.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Jesco Denzel/German Federal Government, via Associated Press

item.title: How Ukraine’s Widows Are Shouldering Their Grief
item.description: It’s impossible to say how many widows the war in Ukraine has created because Kyiv closely guards its casualty figures. But estimates suggest they number in the tens of thousands.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung, Maria Varenikova and Evelina Riabenko
item.media:description: The war in Ukraine has left thousands of widows, and some widowers, across the country struggling to find a way forward.

item.title: Trump’s Election Has Migrants Rethinking Plans to Head to the U.S.
item.description: The incoming president has promised the largest deportation effort in U.S. history. Now migrants are weighing a new Trump administration in deciding whether to trek to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daniel García, a Venezuelan delivery worker living in Bogotá, Colombia, decided to stay there rather than migrate to the United States after Donald J. Trump became president-elect this month.

item.title: Is a ‘Green’ Revolution Poisoning India’s Capital?
item.description: India promised to burn its trash mountains and safely turn them into electricity. But a New York Times investigation found hazardous levels of toxic substances around homes, playgrounds and schools.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Denton

item.title: Shigeru Ishiba Wins Vote to Remain as Japan’s Prime Minister
item.description: Parliament voted Monday to stick with Ishiba, who will lead a minority government after his party suffered heavy losses in an election last month.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, standing, after winning a vote on Monday that will let him stay as Japan’s prime minister.

item.title: Why Did Tens of Thousands of Chinese Students Go on Night Bike Rides?
item.description: Making the impromptu five-hour ride between two Chinese cities became a craze among young people. But as their numbers swelled, the authorities shut it down.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Qian and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The students rode from the city of Zhengzhou, in Henan Province, to the neighboring city of Kaifeng. At first they were welcomed, but their large numbers soon raised safety concerns.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: What Trump means for the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A billboard congratulating Donald Trump in Tel Aviv last week.

item.title: Will Trump Rekindle a Bromance With Kim Jong-un? South Koreans Worry.
item.description: Donald J. Trump’s second term brings uncertainty to the Korean Peninsula as nuclear tensions run high. North Korea’s leader may see a chance to re-engage.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, met for the first time in 2018 on Sentosa Island in Singapore.

item.title: Why Is COP29 Being Held in Baku, Azerbaijan?
item.description: The economy of Azerbaijan, host of COP29, relies almost entirely on the fossil fuels that are the main driver of global warming.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil site near the COP29 venue on the outskirts of Baku, Azerbaijan.

item.title: COP29 talks open in Baku in the shadow of Trump’s election
item.description: The election of Donald J. Trump is sapping momentum from global climate talks as diplomats brace for his pro-fossil-fuel agenda.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman

item.title: Monday Briefing: Russian and North Korean Troops Assemble
item.description: Plus, does tech make us feel lonely?
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army vehicle passing through a destroyed Russian border post.

item.title: Paul Stephenson, 87, Dies; Advanced Britain’s Civil Rights Movement
item.description: The bus boycott and one-man pub sit-in that he led in the mid-1960s helped pave the way for a law outlawing discrimination in public places.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Paul Stephenson in 2005. That year The Independent wrote that his efforts to end discrimination “helped to thrust race into the national limelight and change public opinion about the treatment of Blacks and Asians living in Britain.”

item.title: Trump Should Not Let Putin Claim Victory in Ukraine, Says NATO Official
item.description: Adm. Rob Bauer warned against any peace deal that was too favorable to Russia, arguing that it could undermine American interests.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Admiral Rob Bauer, NATO’s top military official, in September. “It’s important enough to talk about Ukraine on its own, but there is more at stake than just Ukraine,” he said in an interview on Saturday.

item.title: Baltazar Ushca, Who Kept Andean Ice Harvesting Alive, Dies at 80
item.description: He trekked up Ecuador’s tallest mountain twice a week for six decades to hack ice off a glacier with a pickax. He is believed to have been the last of his breed.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Baltazar Ushca in an undated photo extracting ice from the glaciers of Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador. He did this work until about five years ago, when he injured his foot.

item.title: Trevor Sorbie, Creator of the Dorothy Hamill ‘Wedge’ Cut, Dies at 75
item.description: He also styled hair for Helen Mirren, the Beach Boys and others, and he was honored by Queen Elizabeth II for services to British hairdressing.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:description: The hairdresser Trevor Sorbie in 2017.

item.title: Qatar Pauses Role as Israel-Hamas Mediator in Gaza Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The Qatari Foreign Ministry announced it had stepped back from talks, saying it would resume once Israel and Hamas “show willingness and seriousness.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Doha, Qatar, in October. Qatar has hosted Hamas’s exiled political leaders since 2012, making it a key mediator in the talks to reach a cease-fire in the war in Gaza.

item.title: Amsterdam Bars Protests After Antisemitic Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans
item.description: The violence erupted around a soccer match between Israeli and Dutch teams in Amsterdam on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Lynsey Chutel and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Freek Van Den Bergh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Police patrolling in central Amsterdam on Friday after overnight violence.

item.title: U.N.-Backed Panel Urges ‘Immediate Action’ in Gaza to Avert Famine
item.description: The warning focused on the north comes as the Biden administration has set a mid-November deadline for Israel to deliver more humanitarian supplies to the enclave or face a cutoff of weapons aid.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Palestinians trying to buy bread from a bakery in central Gaza in October.

item.title: Playing Favorites
item.description: The foods and music and culture that move us most might not be very good, but that doesn’t diminish their power to comfort and delight.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada Sends Mixed Signals With TikTok Shutdown Order
item.description: The industry minister closed TikTok’s offices in Toronto and Vancouver over security concerns, but Canadians can still download and use the app.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Canada has ordered TikTok to close its offices in Toronto and Vancouver.

item.title: Suicide Bombing in Pakistan Leaves Dozens Dead or Wounded at Quetta Railway Station
item.description: A banned ethnic separatist group in a restive province claimed responsibility for the deadly attack in Quetta, the provincial capital.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Security personnel inspecting the blast area after an explosion at a railway station in Quetta, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Russia Sentences 2 Soldiers Over Killing of Ukrainian Family
item.description: The case, in which two soldiers murdered nine members of a family after breaking into their home, was a rare prosecution over crimes against civilians in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Russian troops guarding a street in Volnovakha, Ukraine, in 2022.

item.title: How We Found the Dangers Threatening Delhi’s ‘Green’ Energy Future
item.description: In the heart of India’s capital, residents blame chronic, debilitating illnesses on an industrial plant burning the city’s garbage and turning it into electricity.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Denton
item.media:description: A truck hauling uncovered ash driving over by a neighborhood park in Khadda Colony, New Delhi.

item.title: A Messy Problem in Orderly Singapore: Keeping Track of Cats
item.description: The reversal of a 35-year ban on cats in public housing won’t be a quick fix for cat-related problems. It’s not even clear how many cats live in the city-state.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Ore Huiying
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times

item.title: Gazans Are Living Through a Yearlong Blackout
item.description: Israel cut off electricity in the first days of the war, leaving Palestinians to light the dark with cellphones and to cook over open flames.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Bilal Shbair
item.media:description: A Palestinian family gathering around a fire on the roof of their destroyed house in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, in September.

item.title: The Long Global Trail of Resentment Behind Trump’s Resurrection
item.description: Disillusionment with the world that emerged from the Cold War has fueled a long-gathering revolt against the established order.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ronald Reagan with the Soviet president, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in 1987. As the Cold War ended, few considered how disorienting the world would become.

item.title: Who Is Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Authoritarian Leader and Friend of Trump?
item.description: The long-serving prime minister, a champion of ‘illiberal democracy,’ has been politically isolated in much of Europe. But he has found common ground with the former and soon-to-be new U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary and Donald J. Trump, then president, at the White House in 2019.

item.title: What to Know About the Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans in Amsterdam
item.description: Dutch and Israeli officials described the clashes after a soccer match as antisemitic. The violence followed two days of tensions in the city.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson, Lynsey Chutel and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers formed a security cordon around a bus after the soccer match in Amsterdam early Friday.

item.title: America’s Wobbly Democracy
item.description: Lessons from a London bridge.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: The Millennium Bridge in London.

item.title: Elon Musk Joined Trump’s Call With Zelensky
item.description: Elon Musk was with Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago when the president-elect spoke with Ukraine’s leader. It is not clear if they discussed any change in U.S. policy toward Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Elon Musk provided the Trump campaign with financial and logistical support.

item.title: Playing Out a Dream, a Long, Long Way From Home
item.description: An academy of a team in England’s lower leagues offers Americans at the end of their collegiate eligibility a chance to continue their soccer careers.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Are England’s lower leagues the new study abroad?

item.title: Party Whose Leader Is Known for Antisemitism to Join Lithuanian Government
item.description: A new coalition includes a party led by a politician notorious for antisemitic remarks, another blow to the longstanding refusal by Europe’s mainstream parties to join with those seen as extremist.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Remigijus Zemaitaitis, leader of a new party, gave up his seat in Parliament this year to avoid impeachment over antisemitic remarks.

item.title: Notre-Dame’s Bells Ring Together for First Time Since Fire
item.description: The sound of Notre-Dame’s bells pealed throughout Paris for the first time since 2019 — a symbol of rebirth as it prepares to reopen next month.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Three new bells, donated by the organizing committee of the Paris Olympics, in front of the Notre-Dame Cathedral on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Hits Ukraine with Drones, Missiles Overnight
item.description: Millions trek to shelters nightly or take their chances at home as unceasing missile and drone attacks drag on. Some Ukrainians are looking — with hope or sarcasm — to Trump for respite.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: People clear debris outside a school damaged by a Russian strike in Odesa, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: With Trump Tariffs Looming, Businesses Try to ‘Run From a Moving Target’
item.description: Companies are filling their warehouses or looking into moving factories as they weigh President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats to impose tariffs on foreign goods.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Companies are reckoning with President-elect Donald J. Trump’s promises to remake international trade by raising the tariffs the United States puts on foreign products.

item.title: Gazan Rescue Service Has Stopped Operating in the North
item.description: Residents had to dig through rubble in search of their neighbors after the main emergency service in Gaza said it had stopped operations in the north because it had come under Israeli attacks.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: Palestinians inspected the damage outside a building that was struck during an Israeli bombardment in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: India Scraps Import Ban on Salman Rushdie’s ‘Satanic Verses’
item.description: In 1988, India issued an order forbidding the import of Salman Rushdie’s novel. A Delhi Court has overturned the order, not because of free speech, but because no one could find it.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: Salman Rushdie in Frankfurt, Germany, last year.

item.title: How My War Came Home
item.description: A reporter thought of his city in the west of Ukraine as a haven from Russian bombs — until a strike hit his street.
item.dc:creator: Yurii Shyvala
item.media:description: Ukrainians gathered at the site of a Russian strike on a residential area of Lviv, in western Ukraine, in September. The yellow apartment building in the background is where the reporter and his family live.

item.title: Hungary’s Viktor Orban and European Far-Right Leaders Welcome Trump’s Return
item.description: Viktor Orban of Hungary and other right-wing European politicians hail the return of a U.S. president who shares their tough views on issues like immigration.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary gambled heavily and publicly on a Trump victory.

item.title: Will Musk Influence Trump on Climate Change and Electric Vehicles?
item.description: The Tesla billionaire is a key figure in the president-elect’s orbit. One question is whether his views on climate and clean energy will have any sway.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: Elon Musk is expected to have a direct line to the White House in the coming months.

item.title: Antisemitic Attacks Prompt Emergency Flights for Israeli Soccer Fans
item.description: Dutch and Israeli officials said the fans had been attacked in Amsterdam after tensions flared around an Israeli team’s visit.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Christopher F. Schuetze, Jin Yu Young and Claire Moses

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Donald Trump proposed an assortment of loosely defined tax cuts during his campaign, but lawmakers and his advisers are undecided about how much they will lower taxes again.

item.title: Ireland to Hold Snap General Election: What to Know
item.description: The Republic of Ireland will hold a general election on Nov. 29, after Prime Minister Simon Harris dissolved parliament on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Simon Harris, the prime minister of Ireland, in Washington last month.

item.title: Argentina Drove Down Teen Pregnancy. Then Came Javier Milei.
item.description: Argentina has been known as one of Latin America’s most socially progressive countries. But President Javier Milei’s austerity measures have cut programs aimed at helping women.
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Natalie Alcoba and Anita Pouchard Serra
item.media:description: Feminist-themed paintings in the small town of Oran, Province of Salta, Argentina.

item.title: Prince William: Past Year Hardest of Life, After Kate and Charles’ Cancer Diagnoses
item.description: While in South Africa for the Earthshot Prize, the prince told reporters that the cancer diagnoses of his wife, Catherine, and his father, King Charles, had been “brutal.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince William was greeted by crowds in South Africa during a visit to Kalk Bay Harbour in Cape Town on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Biden promises a peaceful transition
item.description: Plus, the readers turning to “healing fiction.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden yesterday at the White House.

item.title: Interpol Tightens Oversight After Autocrats Target Its Databases
item.description: The changes are intended to stop governments from using the world’s largest police organization to harass and monitor political dissidents.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Florentina Olareanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: The challenge of policing abuses of Interpol’s systems will fall to the organization’s new secretary general, Valdecy Urquiza of Brazil.
